column2: Pipes allow you to redirect output from one command into input for another command.

The << operator in Ruby is called "shovel" and allows you to append or add an element to a data set.
e.g.

"hello" << " world"
[1,2] << 3

MVC stands for Model-View-Controller. 

Wiki: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model%E2%80%93view%E2%80%93controller

It is used to separate bodies of logic in a meaningful way to separate the concerns of storing data from the concerns of presenting data.
Javascript, like Ruby, is a scripting language. It has functions as first-class citizens, which means they can be passed around like a football and executed at more dynamic moments.

Sinatra is a minimal web framework in Ruby that provides you with just the bare minimum to set up a web server with some convenience. You build up the rest from scratch.

This allows you to build tremendously flexible codebases.

It's a website that allows us to write code to solve a particular problem defined by tests and to have our code nitpicked by other members of the community. Of course, we can also nitpick other people's code.

column1: How to ask questions the smart way
column2:
This is a really good read to figure out how to get people to help you solve your problem.

http://www.catb.org/esr/faqs/smart-questions.html

DOM stands for Document Object Model and it's a way to represent an HTML document (or XML, for that matter) as a tree. For web purposes, we can use CSS selectors to access and maybe modify a particular element in the DOM.

Rake stands for 'Ruby make' and is a Ruby version of the very old, very powerful tool 'make'. Its goal is to allow meta-project work to be executed, that is, not work on the project itself but work ABOUT the project, such as setting up a database or loading junk data or maybe deploying the project.

Sessions are a special part of the contract between a client and a server in the request/response cycle of an HTTP request.

HTTP itself is stateless, but a session allows you to preserve data between requests, thereby giving an impression of continuity. Sessions are the reason why you don't have to actively log in all the time. 

A session exists when the first web request to the server from the client is created and can live for a custom amount of time. By default, when the browser is closed, the session dies. You can store all sorts of information in the session, but you shouldn't, because it takes space in memory (or in a database, etc) and there usually are better ways to store data. 

Only use the session in exceptional circumstances, like authorization/permissions.

This is mostly a test to see how UTF-8 works.

Many-to-many is a type of relationship between tables. For instance, if you had many dogs and many dog_walkers, then a single dog_walker could take a dog on many walks. The walks table would be the many-to-many relationship: a dog can have many dog walkers, a dog walker can have many dogs, both through walks.

The basic SQL relationship. If there are two tables, owners and dogs, and an owner can have many dogs, then:

SELECT owners.name, dogs.name FROM owners INNER JOIN dogs ON owner.id = dogs.owner_id

this will give you the name of the owner and the name of the dog in a table, like so:

owners.name | dogs.name
----------------+--------------
Kathew           |    Jebb
----------------+--------------
Kathew           |   Bog
----------------+--------------
Omily              |    Hooman
